items.title: Invalid permutation test ?
items.body:
Hello,

I was glad to find an implementation of permutation tests to challenge my theoretical understanding of it (and compare with my own).

Actually, it seems that `mlxtend.evaluate.permutation_test` wrongly rejects permutations whose statistic result is equal to the tested statistic (exact tests [here ](https://github.com/rasbt/mlxtend/blob/master/mlxtend/evaluate/permutation.py#L123) and simulations [here](https://github.com/rasbt/mlxtend/blob/master/mlxtend/evaluate/permutation.py#L131)), which leads to lower p-values than desired.

The fix is quite simple. Should I open a PR ? Or did I miss something ?

Thanks

items.title: FPMax Wrong Support?
items.body:
## Test Dataset
I'm using the mushroom dataset which can be found at [here](https://github.com/felipekunzler/frequent-itemset-mining-spark/tree/master/src/main/resources/datasets)

## Versions
Python=3.7.6
mlxtend=0.17.2

## Test Code

```python
# coding=utf-8
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from mlxtend.preprocessing import TransactionEncoder
from mlxtend.frequent_patterns import fpmax


# mushroom dataset
mushroomdata = []
with open("mushroom.txt", "r") as f:
    for line in f.readlines():
        nums = [int(c) for c in line.strip("\n").split(" ") if c != "" and c != "\r"]
        mushroomdata.append(nums)
# trans
te = TransactionEncoder()
mushroomTeArray = te.fit(mushroomdata).transform(mushroomdata)
mushroomDf = pd.DataFrame(mushroomTeArray, columns=te.columns_)
# MFI, min-sup = 0.3
mushroomMfIDf = fpmax(mushroomDf, min_support=0.3, use_colnames=True)
mushroomMfIDf["count"] = len(mushroomdata) * mushroomMfIDf.support
mushroomMFI = mushroomMfIDf[["itemsets", "count"]]
mushroomMFI["itemsets"] = mushroomMFI["itemsets"].apply(lambda x: tuple(sorted(x)))

```
And the last output is `(34, 39, 59, 63, 85, 86, 90)`  with a support `2696.0`. BUT, the true support of the MFI is `2504`.
```python
i = 0                                                                                                                                                                                              
for row in mushroomdata: 
    if len(set(row) & {34, 39, 59, 63, 85, 86, 90}) == 7: 
        i += 1 
print(i)
```

items.title: Single Path in FPTree
Out of memory problem with sequential forward selection
items.body:
Hey :-)

I have a problem where my computer runs out of memory, when using the Sequential Feature *Forward* Selection.
I have a moderate sized dataset of roughly 2gb of data, but over 2000 features I am selecting from on all cores of the machine.

The computer:
256gb ram
48 cores
Ubuntu 18.04
Python 3.6

As far as i can tell the problem is in the implementation of the parallel backend. It copies the full data to the subprocess and then does the slicing there. On a backward selection this should be find, but for forward only a partial of that data is actually needed. 
I would propose doing the slicing before calling the _calc_score function.

items.title: Adding scoring_func that depend on y_predict_proba to bootstrap methods
items.body:
**Problem**
Currently, mlxtend bootstrapping procedures require the `scoring_func` to take `y_true` and `y_predict`. However, metrics like AUC, depend on `y_true` and `y_predict_proba` instead.

**Suggested Soln**
This could potentially be enabled by adding a kwarg to the bootstrapping functions that say `predict_proba=False` to determine which sklearn classifier prediction to use. It could be added around this line: https://github.com/rasbt/mlxtend/blob/57aa05aef85315e2dde56abc0b77e4864fde9d15/mlxtend/evaluate/bootstrap_point632.py#L162

This seems like it could potentially be an easy addition, but idk how @rasbt feels about adding an additional kwarg to the bootstrapping funcs?

**Misc**
I can submit a PR if so. Lmk if you want me to add any unit tests as well?

items.title: Error while rendering the confusion matrix saved as .pgf in LaTeX
items.body:
`mlxtend` is a great package, and the `plot_confusion_matrix` routine has been super useful to me. 

However, I encountered a problem when saving the confusion matrix as a pgf file and then rendering it in LaTeX. I think the issue is with `imshow` command, but just checking if you have any solution. Below is a minimum working example:

```
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import os
from os import path
from mlxtend.plotting import plot_confusion_matrix
import matplotlib as mpl

nice_fonts = {
        "font.family" : "serif",
        "text.usetex" : True,
}

mpl.rcParams.update(nice_fonts)


fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,1)
cm = np.array([[12,18],[1,49]])
_class_labels_cm = {'class1' : 0,
                  'class2' : 1}
class_names = [k for k,v in _class_labels_cm.items()]

plot_confusion_matrix(conf_mat=cm,
                                colorbar=False,
                                show_absolute=True,
                                show_normed=False, axis = ax,hide_ticks = False,figure=fig)

fig_path = path.join(os.getcwd(),os.pardir)
fig.savefig(path.join(fig_path,'cm.pgf'), format='pgf', bbox_inches='tight')
```
Along with the pgf file, it also saves a png image of the background 'cm-img0.png' and this actually creates an issue in LaTeX. I am using LuaLaTeX to compile. Any lead is much appreciated. I am sorry if this not the right place to raise this issue since this is technically an issue with pgf and LaTeX. 

Cheers!

items.title: About clustering on mixed data-types datasets
items.body:
Dear Sebastian,

I have a real dataset with both numeric and categorical attributes. The first algorithm taken into account was k-means or DBSCAN (given that I used to work with continuous numeric data and, if categorical, an numeric ordinal value was implicit, being able to re-scale via standard-scaling afterwards).

Nevertheless, when having categorical values with no real distance in between, one idea could be applying one-hot-encoding, although as far as I know it is not a good idea when using similarity metrics like SSE as done with k-means, but another merics like k-modes (as proposed in this [paper](http://www.cs.ust.hk/~qyang/Teaching/537/Papers/huang98extensions.pdf)), or the mixed version k-prototypes. Do you have any recommendation/knowledge about clustering on mixed data types?
It is strange that, as far as I could check in Scikit-Learn, they do not seem to mention this option in their Clustering module. I found [this library](https://github.com/nicodv/kmodes) which could apply that algorithm. 
Some other source of info in discussions [here](https://datascience.stackexchange.com/questions/22/k-means-clustering-for-mixed-numeric-and-categorical-data)

Thanks in advance, and as always, congrats for your great book and mlxtend.

Germán

items.title: Questions on no_information_rate calculation
items.body:
I am trying to modify your `no_information_rate` function to make it suitable for `roc_auc_score` function of `sklearn` for example which takes as argument the output of `estimator.decision_function(X)` for binary problems. Thus, it doesn't work in the current form of the function where you get the output of `estimator.predict(X)` as argument. I have some idea to generalize the calculation for any scorer but it doesn't work with the current implementation and especially with `np.meshgrid` so I tried to use something else but I can't find the same results as your function. 
As far as I understood the equation given in the original publication, here is what I should do in case of accuracy:
```
import numpy as np
from itertools import product
from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score

for i in range(y.shape[0]):
    for j in range(y.shape[0]):
        pred = est.predict(X[j, :].reshape(1, -1))
        combinations.append(1 if pred == y[i] else 0)
no_information_rate = np.mean(combinations)

# Or equivalent to
combinations = []
for i in range(y.shape[0]):
    for j in range(y.shape[0]):
        combinations.append(np.array([y[i], est.predict(X[j, :].reshape(1, -1))[0]]))
no_information_rate = accuracy_score(np.array(combinations)[:, 0], np.array(combinations)[:, 1])

# Or more simplier
combinations = np.array(list(product(y, est.predict(X))))
no_information_rate = accuracy_score(combinations[:, 0], combinations[:, 1])
```

Am I misunderstanding something in the calculation of the no information rate?

items.title: Add a `refit` parameter to the StackingClassifier and StackingCVClassifier (similar to the EnsembleVoteClassifier)
items.body:
Hi! First of all thanks for an awesome package @rasbt :) Secondly, I wasn't able to find a similar question but I apologize in case it's a copy. It's essentially quite simple:

1) I have some data on which I have divided in into train/ test as well as a repeated CV scheme with a given random seed to have reproducible results

2) I have trained and optimised hyperparameters of both underlying base models through CV

3) I would like now to train a meta learner on top that would be Elastic-Net and I would like to tune it's hyperparameters using CV as well

If I understand correctly, currently I would need to do something like this:

```
stack_meta = LogisticRegression()

stack_pipeline = StackingClassifier(
    classifiers = [grid_search_rf, grid_search_en], 
    meta_classifier = stack_meta, 
    use_probas = True
    )

grid_param_stack = {'meta_classifier__C': [2**i for i in range(-2,1)]}

grid_search_stack = GridSearchCV(estimator = stack_pipeline, 
                                 param_grid = grid_param_stack, 
                                 scoring = ['roc_auc'],
                                 cv = cv_splits,
                                 refit = 'roc_auc',
                                 n_jobs = 4)
```

My expectation was that since I'm providing tuned underlying classifiers, the ```StackingClassifier``` function would simply aggregate hold-out predictions from CV of my base models, and use them as inputs for tuning the final meta learner while using the same CV scheme. That should normally take a matter of a couple of seconds, but it seems that StackingClassifier is reffing the underlying models as well.

How can I achieve what I want with the current implementation of the function? I couldn't find a definitive answer in the documentation. Thanks!

items.title: Mlxtend to support categorical data in plot_decision_regions
items.body:
Hi there,

Thanks for your work! I'm happily using `plot_decision_regions` to visualize the decision boundary for my Keras models.

I'm currently experimenting with loss functions to get a feel for how they work. Currently, my (very simple) setup is as follows for testing how the Keras implementation of `categorical_hinge` (multiclass hinge loss) works:

1. I generate a test dataset with Scikit's `make_blobs` containing three separable clusters, like this:

![3clust](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6450612/66864632-e143e700-ef95-11e9-9ec8-899d2480320a.png)

2. I create a simple MLP architecture in Keras that computes loss by means of `categorical_hinge`. The model learns to classify the testing data into the correct cluster successfully.

However, when plotting the decision boundaries with Mlxtend's `plot_decision_regions`, I run into this error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "multiclass-hinge.py", line 56, in <module>
    plot_decision_regions(X_testing, Targets_testing_nonc, clf=model, legend=3)
  File "C:\Users\chris\Anaconda3\envs\tensorflow_gpu\lib\site-packages\mlxtend\plotting\decision_regions.py", line 231, in plot_decision_regions
    Z = Z.reshape(xx.shape)
ValueError: cannot reshape array of size 921600 into shape (480,640)
```

I believe it originates from the fact that my target data has to be one-hot encoded in order to allow Keras to apply categorical hinge loss. This belief is strengthened by the fact that 921600 divided by 640 is 1440, which itself divided by 3 (number of clusters and hence given one-hot encoding number of target values per target sample, e.g. [1 0 0] ) is the requested 480.

Why this problem emerges is because the actual `model clf` used by Mlxtend produces one-hot encoded outputs itself, which apparently goes wrong in Mlxtend.

With this issue, I'm hoping that I can request support for categorical data in the `plot_decision_regions` function. If I'm wrong in my interpretation of this error, I'd appreciate to find out how I can make this visualization run. 

Thanks very much!

items.title: FPGrowth and Apriori disagreement with minsup=0
items.body:
Noticed this when fixing other bug. There is a disagreement between FPGrowth and Apriori when minsupport=0. I am not sure what the answer should be.

Support your input itemsets are `[[a], [b]]`. 

```
itemsets = [['a'],['b']]
te = TransactionEncoder()
te_ary = te.fit(rs).transform(itemsets)
df = pd.DataFrame(te_ary, columns=te.columns_)
print(fpgrowth(df, min_support=0))
print(apriori(df, min_support=0))
```
This produces:
```
   support itemsets
0      0.5      (a)
1      0.5      (b)
   support itemsets
0      0.5      (a)
1      0.5      (b)
2      0.0   (b, a)
```

We should make it consistent, but which one? The second is correct in a theoretical sense (every possibly subset of all items appears at least 0 times), but the first is probably more useful in the practical sense.

items.title: Optimization of apriori algorithm by replacing iterator with matrix operations
items.body:
Currently, the apriori implementation constructs a set of possible item combinations then iterates through this set to determine which combinations have a support above `min_support`. This iteration is slow and can be replaced by matrix equality operations and/or arithmetic. I propose the following changes:

```
    while max_itemset and max_itemset < (max_len or float('inf')):
        next_max_itemset = max_itemset + 1
        combin = np.array(list(generate_new_combinations(itemset_dict[max_itemset])))

        if combin.size == 0:
            break

        if verbose:
            print('\rProcessing %d combinations | Sampling itemset size %d' %
                  (combin.size[0], next_max_itemset), end="")

        if is_sparse:
            all_ones = np.ones((int(rows_count), 1))
            _bools = X[:, combin[:, 0]] == all_ones
            for n in range(1, combin.shape[1]):
                _bools = _bools & (X[:, combin[:, n]] == all_ones)
        else:
            _bools = np.all(X[:, combin], axis=2)

        support = _support(np.array(_bools), rows_count, is_sparse)
        _mask = (support >= min_support).reshape(-1)

        if any(_mask):
            itemset_dict[next_max_itemset] = np.array(combin[_mask])
            support_dict[next_max_itemset] = np.array(support[_mask])
            max_itemset = next_max_itemset
        else:
            break
```

In practice, this implementation is much faster than the current implementation, albeit at the cost of a slightly increased memory footprint: 

https://gist.github.com/jmayse/ad688d6a7fd842269996a701d7cecd4c

However, it usually remains slower than the `fpgrowth` implementation, as is expected:

https://gist.github.com/jmayse/7c76a2d838ac164b923a47b29527f2ed

I am facing an issue with the sequential feature selector. I am not sure if the issue is with mlxtend or scikit-learn (or something else) but I am giving it a try here.

This is my code, roughly:

```
from sklearn.model_selection import ParameterGrid, GridSearchCV, StratifiedKFold
```

items.title: a problem about StackingCVClassifier
Allow tuning of the inner and outer estimators in SequentialFeatureSelector simultaneously
items.body: Currently, it is not possible to tune both the inner and outer estimators when using SequentialFeatureSelector in a pipeline with another estimator (when using GridSearchCV, for example). This can be fixed by modifying the code according to the changes proposed in #515

items.title: Make Stacking classes capable of replacing regressors/classifiers in GridSearchCV
items.body: Apply the refactoring proposed in #515 to allow changing the first level and meta classifiers/regressors at the same time via GridSearchCV etc.

items.title: Add a "verbose" option to apriori
items.body: I think the `apriori` function would benefit from a `verbose` option (with default: `verbose=0`) to optionally show some output during processing, which may be useful if a large dataset is passed, to indicate whether the algorithm got stuck or whether it is still progressing.

items.title: The same `random_state` param for all models in stacked_models
items.body:
It would be convenient to set the same `random_state` parameter value for stacked models and metamodel in classes:
- StackingClassifier
- StackingCVClassifier
- StackingRegressor
- StackingCVRegressor
I suggest the following backward compatible changes in API:
- new constructor param `random_state=None` - for all models (if None - do not set `random_state` param of models)
- new constructor param `meta_random_state=None` - for meta models (if None, use `random_state` param)
I can take to work implementation of this issue

items.title: Feature Request - Frequent Patterns
items.body:
Suggestion to add **FP-Growth** and **Top-k Frequent itemsets** mining in frequent patterns library.

It would be great if mlxtend could have these 2 major algorithms which are also great for mining frequent patterns. It will be great if we can have all such tools in a single package.

Currently, the best FP-Growth implementation is in [Orange3](https://github.com/biolab/orange3-associate/blob/master/orangecontrib/associate/fpgrowth.py), but it doesn't have max_len which is a very big limitation when it comes to mining patterns in a large database.
As for top-k frequent itemsets mining, I didn't find any good library to use for production, it would be really great if these 2 can be added.

items.title: ColumnSelector has the bug to select columns
items.body:
Dear Developers,

In ColumnSelector.py, the parameter of cols was recommended with using tuple or list, 
which was written and used on API documents,  
> cols : array-like (default: None)' http://rasbt.github.io/mlxtend/user_guide/feature_selection/ColumnSelector/  

but in class ColumnSelector line 79 to 81 as 
 ```
if hasattr(X, 'loc'):   
  t = X.loc[:, self.cols].values
else:     
  t = X[:, self.cols] 
```
and it dosen't work.

'loc' is used with the index of pandas, and X[:, self.cols] doesn't work,
so I think it should be replaced as 'iloc' to the method on API document,
```
if hasattr(X, 'loc'):   
  t = X.iloc[:, self.cols].values
```
and use a list only, it works well (tuple didn't work).

Sincerely,

items.title: Fit Base Estimators with some data (Train Split #1) but fit Meta Estimator with the predictions of different data (Train Split #2)
items.body:
I think there is a problem that if any of your Base Estimators overfits your training data, if the Meta Estimator is trained with the same data split, it will also overfit, because it will always select the accurate prediction for training that will come from the overfitted model.

One solution is to try to avoid models that overfit, but the best solution (because it generalizes more) is to train the Meta Estimator with the predicted probas of the trained Base Estimators but in another holded out training dataset (call it Training Dataset num 2), so it will be fitted with the truly best results of the Base Estimators, because if one Base Estimator is overfitted but does not perform well in validation, the Meta Estimator will not select it (or will give the overfitted Base Estimator a low weight).

tl;dr: title
How can I achieve this witl mlxtend's StackingClassifier?


Thanks in advance.

items.title: sort eigen vector in PrincipalComponentAnalysis
items.body:
https://github.com/rasbt/mlxtend/blob/a4bcab8564841ff39ccd49d69ae077b163763dbd/mlxtend/feature_extraction/principal_component_analysis.py#L143-L153
Because [the column v[:,i] is the eigenvector](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.linalg.eig.html), 
https://github.com/rasbt/mlxtend/blob/a4bcab8564841ff39ccd49d69ae077b163763dbd/mlxtend/feature_extraction/principal_component_analysis.py#L152
should be 
```python
e_vals, e_vecs = e_vals[sort_idx], e_vecs[:, sort_idx]
```
